He grew up in Limerick, the son of pig buyer also called Kennedy O’Brien.

It was a name that goes back for generations and census records of 1911 show eleven men of that name in the country, most of them in the Limerick area, and none born too far away. There might have been more men of the same name only the Catholic Church didn’t like children to be baptised anything other than a saint’s name, but family lore claims that Kennedy Senior - or possibly Kennedy Senior Senior, or possibly any of the men looking to have their child named Kennedy - threatened the priest that if the Catholic Church wouldn’t baptise the child with the selected name, then they would go round the corner and have the latest Kennedy baptised into the Church of Ireland.

Our Kennedy seems was aged 22 at the 1911 Census and was listed as an accountant.

As a young man, he had passed some exams and was all set to move to Dublin in a few months’ time to pursue a workaday job in his chosen field. However, Young Kennedy was approached by the owner of O’Callaghan’s Tannery in Limerick, a man who doubled up as mayor of Limerick. This tannery was the last vestige of a once-thriving leather industry in Ireland which had been in decline ever since livestock began being exported safely to Britain in the 1820s.

Mr O’Callaghan told Kennedy that he had some immediate work for the lad and that he could head off to Dublin when the time came. The lad must have had a good head for numbers, and a reputation for it too, as he was tasked with calculating the number of hides O’Callaghan would be needing for various tasks. Kennedy O’Brien would stay with O’Callaghan for many years to come and he worked his way up the company.


In time he became a Travelling Salesman for O’Callaghan, a job then known as a ‘traveller’ and his role was to sell the tannery’s leather to the shoemakers and shoe repair shops around the entire island of Ireland as partition was yet to be implemented. This gave O’Brien a great appreciation of the needs of the people and how badly employment was needed around the country.

Subsequently the Portlaw Spinning Co. took over the mill but the company had a short life span survive closing in 1904. My families involvement with Portlaw started when my grandfather Kennedy O’Brien set up Irish Leathers in 1920 taking over the factory buildings in Portlaw in 1932 and employing several hundred employees at the height of the tanning industry until the introdution of plastics into shoe making which heralded the downfall of the leather industry in Ireland and the company closed in 1980.

I met Tom O’Brien at his own home, where we spoke about the day his father started work in a tanning factory in Limerick city, run by the O’Callaghans. He described his father’s early days growing up in the city, and his involvement with the Garryowen Rugby Club in the early 1900s. The family moved to Dublin in 1927, where his father set up business as a wholesale leather merchant under the title of Kennedy O’Brien and Company Ltd (Kennedy was his father’s Christian name, a name which can be traced back in the O’Brien clan). Tom himself began work in his father’s tannery in Milford in 1948.

The young priest spoke in 1919 to the Gaelic Society of New York about “The Irish Brigade”


We saw in the last post that The Very Reverand Monsignor Richard J Casey amassed a sizeable collection of slides from talks he gave during his time in New York (1915-20) and then afterwards in Ireland during the early years of The Fres State. This time I want to talk about the Revolutionary nature of these talks. Their subject matter, the venues and the newspaper reports, mostly based on newspaper clippings that Casey kept, but also based on more general research into the topic of funding drives in America.
It is not clear how many talks Casey gave but we have newspaper clippings of several lectures between 1917 and 1919. I can’t yet work out exactly when the talks became heavily politicised, but in 1916 there were reports of him giving ‘Lenten Sermons’ about the religiosity of Irish faithful back home
It is not clear exactly when Casey began giving presentations with slides, but there is one clipping from 1916 which reports him giving ‘Lenten Sermons’ about the religiosity of Irish faithful back home. By 1917, he is talking about life in Beautiful Ireland, as we know from his slides. But his talk has also been politicised a lot, and The Gaelic American reports that ”
"[Casey] took occasion at every appropriate time, to demonstrate alleged pernicious results of English misrule in the country."
Clearly, the audience were on the same page as the reports that:
The photographs of Easter Week, 1916, were wildly applauded. 
One such name was The Gaelic Society, and by January 1919, Casey was presenting at one of their céilidhthe, a combination that shows how revolutionary fervour could be drummed up amidst a cultural event, and a reminder that the Irish cultural revolution really holds primacy over the political revolution.

A flyer for Casey’s presentation on Beautiful Ireland - ‘illustrated in picture, song and story’.


Among the revolutionary fervour, there are slides of Wolfe Tone who led the failed rebellion of 1798, Parnell’s body lying in state, and the bronze statue of Fr William Casey in Abbeyfeale, Co. Limerick. This Casey – who is no relation to our subject – must have been quite the role model for our Richard. He was a Gaelgeoir, musician, GAA man, and temperance activist, which I suspect Fr Richard was too. Fr William was most active in the Land League, for which he gained huge local support, and so was Fr Richard’s uncle – another Fr Richard J Casey – to whom I shall one day return. There are no slides related to the Fenian Uprising of 1867, even though its veteran John Devoy had become the leading Republican in New York by the time of Casey’s lectures. This may be because the Fenians tried to keep a low profile and used codenames for their gatherings.



asdlfkj


Casey’s lecture to The Gaelic Society was about ‘The Irish Brigade”, a term used to refer to each sub-unit of the Irish Republican Army, and in May 1919 he was performing at The Central Opera House for between 1200 and 1800 listeners. This venue was used for ’ethnic theatre’ and it occasionally showed films about Ireland.




St Boniface Holy Name Society


It’s important to note here that these events were not dull lectures, but an ‘illustration’ of Ireland ‘in picture, song and story’. Clearly, Casey was an experienced orator from his sermons, but he was a keen musician and collaborated above with Professor Patrick J McNamara who (need to confirm) ran the St Boniface Holy Name Society. The photo above shows their band – taken from a lantern slide – and, a couple of years after Casey returned home, McNamara wrote to him to lament that there were no more pupils entering the Feis Ceoil. In Casey’s time, his pupils won gold and silver medals. Clearly the band were an ideal segue between the talk and the céilidhe.
The music would have had the other function of rousing the audience’s political sentiments and encouraging them to donate. In the same month as Casey’s talk in the Central Opera House, there were reports of $19,000 being raised in New York for the Irish cause. No doubt that increased over time as about a quarter of a million would be raised in America for the First Dail Loan. Casey himself contributed to this which we know because his scrapbook contains receipts of the bonds he himself bought. But his role was not as a financial contributor, but as a trusted man of influence who could rouse others to donate their cash.
It was this skill that would prove influential years later when it was time for his younger brother Austie to raise money for the factory in Dungarvan.

It’s important to note here that these events were not dull lectures, but an ‘illustration’ of Ireland ‘in picture, song and story’. Clearly, Casey was an experienced orator from his sermons, but he was a keen musician and collaborated above with Professor Patrick J McNamara who (need to confirm) ran the St Boniface Holy Name Society. The photo above shows their band – taken from a lantern slide – and, a couple of years after Casey returned home, McNamara wrote to him to lament that there were no more pupils entering the Feis Ceoil. In Casey’s time, his pupils won gold and silver medals. Clearly the band were an ideal segue between the talk and the céilidhe.
The music would have had the other function of rousing the audience’s political sentiments and encouraging them to donate. In the same month as Casey’s talk in the Central Opera House, there were reports of $19,000 being raised in New York for the Irish cause. No doubt that increased over time as about a quarter of a million would be raised in America for the First Dail Loan. Casey himself contributed to this which we know because his scrapbook contains receipts of the bonds he himself bought. But his role was not as a financial contributor, but as a trusted man of influence who could rouse others to donate their cash.
It was this skill that would prove influential years later when it was time for his younger brother Austie to raise money for the factory in Dungarvan.

title: The Fr. Casey Collection
text:
The Fr Casey collection includes photos he took or amassed during his lifetime, along with many lantern slides (above) which he would have projected to his large audiences in America and later in Ireland. The collection is now housed by the National Photography Archive in Temple Bar, Dublin, where it has been partly sorted and labeled.

title: The Fr. Casey Collection
text:
Beautiful Ireland



The images chosen by Casey give us an idea of the image of Ireland he wanted to convey to his diasporan audience in America. We have a map on the unpartitioned island, some shrivelled up shamrocks, and meticulously preserved castles dating from an ancient time that remains barely fathomable to a New World audience.


The slides that Casey chose portray a land of “emerald hills, the castles of ancient prestige, as well as the modern cities, towns, people and social customs of the old land’, according to one contemporary newspaper report. We have a map of the unpartitioned island, some shrivelled up shamrocks, and meticulously preserved castles dating from an ancient time that must have seemed barely fathomable to his New World audience. There’s The Rock of Cashel, a round tower on Devinish Island in Fermanagh, and the rope bridge near the Giant’s Causeway. Casey includes some images of County Watarford, including the Historic Town of Lismore, Reginald’s Tower in Waterford City, and his own parish church in Dungarvan. There’s an image of a thatched cottage and one (I didn’t see) of Croagh Patrick, a pilgrimage site. There’s a notable lack of barren wild landscapes of the kind Americans like to visit nowadays (e.g. the Ring of Kerry, The Burren, Donegal, etc). There is one of Kilkee in West Clare but I see it either so I don’t know if it’s a photo of the town or the nearby landscapes.

title: The Fr. Casey Collection
text:
Friends of Irish Freedom



Casey includes an image of the already ancient Theobald Wolfe Tone, but no slides show the Fenian Rebellion of 1867


It is interesting to note Casey’s choice of rebels and reformers. One slide shows Wolfe Tone, who led the failed rebellion of 1798. Another shows the Wicklow Parliamentarian, Charles Stewart Parnell, his deceased body lying in state. Finally, there is bronze statue of Fr William Casey in Abbeyfeale, Co. Limerick, the “peoples’ priest”. This Casey – who is also no relation to our subject – must have functioned as quite the role model for our Richard. He was a Gaelgeoir, a musician, a GAA man, and temperance activist, which I suspect Fr Richard was too. Fr William was most active in the Land League, for which he gained huge local support, and so too was Fr Richard’s uncle – another Fr Richard J Casey – to whom I shall one day return. There are no slides related to the Fenian Uprising of 1867, even though its veteran John Devoy had become the leading Republican in New York by the time of Casey’s lectures. This may be because the Fenians tried to keep a low profile and used codenames for their gatherings. Plus the audience may simply have been familiar with Devoy or the recently-deceased O’Donovan Rossa, and would thus have had no need to slides of them.
In my next post, we will see that Casey’s talks may have been part of a series of covert funding campaigns for the Revolution.. For example. one 1919 soirée saw both a céilidhe and Casey’s (music-filled) presentation. It was held by the Gaelic Society in New York. We shall also see newspaper reports of how Casey’s was not afraid to include his thoughts on the English oppressors of the Irish people.

title: The Fr. Casey Collection
text:
Lourdes





In 1913, Casey also seems to have been part of very large group of Irish pilgrims to Lourdes: 3000 in total, including 300 priests and another 200 with a religious affiliation, according to the newspaper clippings above, one in French and one in English, and both of which Casey had upscaled into a lantern slide. This pèlerinage seems to have been one of the events of the year for the Lourdais and it would have been quite the journey for the pilgrims on the boat and train. It would no doubt have been quite the badge of honour in New York too. Even today my parents are very proud of their visit to the miraculous site – although they did cycle there (and back) from Paris during their 1990s cycling-getaway heyday.





There are plenty of photos taken in Lourdes do but I never got to see them. I had it in my head Casey went later but perhaps he went several times, as has since become common. I used to live beside two spinster sisters, just off Meath St, and they had then been volunteering on trips to Lourdes for 25 uninterrupted years, and their living room contained a shrine full of tat. I must drop in some time, armed with a bottle of their beloved vodka, and excavate a few stories from them.

Back in The Free State



This slide shows General Richard Mulcahy hoisting the flag of Irish Free State in 1922


Casey returned to Ireland in the summer of 1920 and moved to Bray soon after, before finally joining hte Defence Forces as chaplain in 1924. Before seeing the collection, I hadn’t realised that he continued to give projected talks after his return to Ireland but the age of the slides indicate that he must have. There are several slides dating from Casey’s time back in the Auld Sod, and the ones I saw relate to the newly formed Free State in the early 1920s. One shows General Richard Mulcahy hoisting the Irish flag in 1922 and one shows an aerial view of a damaged Four Courts, bombed and burnt during the Civil War. Another shows troops marching to Dolphin’s Barn Barracks from DMP Barracks (which is now the public library in an oddly vacant part of Inchicore). Another aerial shot shows President Cosgrave returning to Monkstown from a League of Nations meeting in 1923, being greeted by crowds who were clearly delighted to see the new state being recognised among the nations of the world. Casey’s scrapbook contains a flyer from April 1922 where he spoke to the Catholic Young Men’s Society on Buckingham St (on the town side of Phibsborough), but the above slides were mostly taken after that.



Casey spoke to the CYM society in Dublin in 1922, but must have continued beyond this, judging by the date of the slides.




The Archivists’ Records



Catalogue details of the Fr Casey collection


Above is the full catalogue record of the collection, with information about what is in the collection, the number of photos, slides and negatives, their condition, and the subject matter. If I can get back in with John Harte, there will be plenty more to sift through.


Yet more Caseys
Finally, I should note that, while I was the first member of the public to view the collection, I wasn’t the first to request to view it. It turns out that a genealogist called Paul O’Donnell was in touch with Nora and her colleague Barbara but Covid interrupted his efforts to view it and then, shurlook, you know yourself. So while I was in on site, Barbara found his email, contacted him with my details, and by the end of the day we had a 40 minute phone conversation about the Casey family. It turns out that O’Donnell is married to a Casey from Grawn – the crowd who moved in there after it was sold – and he has done quite a bit of work on the wider family, although his brain is fried by the incessant recurrence of people with the same name (Richard, Pierce, Michael, etc). I will write about that conversation soon, or perhaps after I trek Co Galway to find out more from him.

1830s Peak
The emergence of a leather industry in 1930s Ireland was akin to a resurrection from a long and painful death. The previous hundred years had seen a steady decline of a once-flourishing native industry. The peak was in the 1820s and ’30s around the time that livestock began to be exported en masse to Britain, thanks to improvements in sea communications, and thus there fewer and fewer hides available for tanning. In 1837 there were 46 tanneries in the city of Cork alone, tanning over 2000 hides per week. and employing 625 people, which is more people than were employed across the twenty-six counties at the height of the resurrection in the 1950s. To grasp the proliferation of the industry in comparison, it may be instructive to compare it to sports clubs in the modern day. Currently, there are 225 GAA clubs in the county of Cork alone, and over 1600 hundred on the island, whereas there are just 109 rugby clubs on the island, many of them clustered in a few hubs. And just as almost every parish nowadays has its own GAA club, every town and village in pre-famine Ireland would have had a tanyard, alongside at least one person making shoes and another repairing them.
Decline
By 1852, after The Great Hunger had destroyed the nation, there were still 26 tanneries in Cork City, although few of them were operating full-time as demand for leather had understandably dropped and credit was scarce so the businesses couldn’t get back on their feet. By 1902, there were just three tanneries in Cork and just 18 across the entire island of Ireland. In 1923, when a Free State report was commissioned, there were just five. The only large-scale operation was Callaghans in Limerick City, tanning 200 hides per week, and small operation in Thomastown, Clonmel, Ballitore and New Ross, tanning just 100 hiders per week between them. In total, these tanneries were supplying on one twentieth of the state’s demand for leather, so the other 95% had to be imported. Even so, New Ross would close down the following year.
The reasons for the decline of the leather industry thus provide us with something of a microcosm of the problems that Ireland faced during the tragic century between the 1820s and 1920s. A tannery needs two things more than anything else: animal skins and dyes for tanning, and both of these were being purged from the country. Livestock were shipped to Britain in ever-increasing numbers and with them vanished the jobs associated with processing the animals, such as butchering the flesh and tanning the skins. Meanwhile, dyes taken from oak bark were becoming harder to source due to deforestation, although by our time of interest, different dyes were being used. A completely different, and preventable problem, was in how duties were levied on tanners. In England, tanners paid duty on every hide processed whereas in Ireland they paid duty on the pits used for processing them, so too many hides would be processed in the one pit, resulting in lower quality leather being made throughout Ireland, and thus greater demand for leather imported from across the pond. Finally, there was little hope of any Irish tanneries exporting leather to Britain, seeing as Britain imposed a 60% tariff on Irish leather but there was only a 10% tariff in the opposite direction.
Shoots of growth
Between 1922 and 1932, there was no improvement in the leather industry, although there was a little growth in the footwear industry and these helped paved the way for native leather production which could then be used as a raw material for footwear. In 1924, small tariffs of 15% were introduced on footwear sales in Ireland, but British manufacturers were mostly efficient enough to outprice the emerging batch of Irish producers. However, UK-based businesses began to arrive in The Free State with Edward Donaghy bringing his entire business over the border to Dundalk and, in 1928, John Halliday of Leeds also set up a factory in Dundalk. Later, County Louth would become something of a hub for the Irish footwear industry. title: Kennedy O’Brien and the Portlaw Tannery
text:
The Tannery in Portlaw was huge but its output complemented its Dungarvan counterpart.1
Kennedy O’Brien was one of the few bona fide leather men left in early Free State Ireland by which time the tanning industry had dwindled almost entirely out of existence. Yet over the next few decades he helped to build up the industry more than any other person on the ground and his story is an interesting contrast to his colleague-to-be, Austie Casey, because O’Brien was focussed single-mindedly on leather and nothing else, plus he also lived longer to see out his ambitions.
Kennedy O’Brien grew up in Limerick, the son of pig buyer also called Kennedy O’Brien. Kennedy was a given name that went back for generations in that branch of the family and census records of 1911 show eleven men in Ireland of that name, possibly all them related as most of them were in the Limerick area, and only one lived improbably far away. There might have been even more Kennedy O’Briens, only the Catholic Church didn’t like children to be baptised with anything other than a saint’s name, although family lore claims that there was a cheeky way of twisting the church’s arm. Our Kennedy’s father simply told the Parish Priest that if he didn’t let his son be baptised with the preferred name, then the child would be brought round the corner and baptised a Protestant. This did the trick and thus the curious, heavy-duty, forename lived on.
Our Kennedy O’Brien was aged 22 at the 1911 census, making him a full decade older than Austie. He was listed as an accountant but may have already begun working in O’Callaghan’s Tannery in Limerick City, the last surviving large-scale tannery on the island. He was head-hunted by the Managing Director, Michael O’Callaghan, who would serve as Mayor of Limerick before being murdered in 1921, likely by the Black and Tans or the RIC Auxiliaries.2 But O’Callaghan said he needed someone to help him estimate the number of hides needed in the factory – clearly a job suited to a man of numbers – but O’Brien already had a job lined up in Dublin and was due to begin a few months later. O’Callaghan said that the clever young man was free to leave when his other job was ready to start. O’Brien took the job and clearly found his place in the world as he spent the rest of his life selling and making leather, as well as spawning a handful of sons who followed him into the trade.
Having established himself within the Limerick tannery buildings, and built the trust of his boss, O’Brien was given a car and sent out to sell O’Callaghan’s leather to the shoemakers and shoe repair shops of Ireland – all thirty-two counties, as partition was yet to be implemented. This constant movement suited his restless nature and it also gave him a great appreciation of the needs of the Irish people, their need for more employment, and the country’s need for a native tanning industry, rather than importing almost all of its leather from Britain, much of it made from the hides of exported Irish livestock.
In 1927, O’Brien set up his own business as a wholesale leather merchant, on 27 North Frederick St in Dublin City, and that building would become the centre of operations for his ever-expanding leather empire. It must have been around this time that he became friendly with Sean Lemass3 who became known for cavorting with city businessmen, playing golf by day or poker at night. Yet cronyism aside, there is unlikely to have been anyone better suited than O’Brien to the task of planning a native tanning industry, between his years of experience, his knowledge of the entire country from his time on the road, and his deep zeal for employment creation. Thus having the Dublin man’s ear would prove most invaluable once the Fianna Fail government took control of the country in 1932 and set out their twin policies of protectionism and decentralization, leading to the establishment of so many factories around the towns of Ireland, big and small. By the mid 1930s, O’Brien’s Dublin business was firmly established, so he would have the time and energy to throw into the Portlaw venture.
Why Portlaw?
The choice of a settlement as small as Portlaw might seem odd for such a large operation, but DJ Dwyer, in his 1962 study of the Irish Tanning industry, considers it something of a prototypical choice for a tannery. One requirement was easy access to a port (Waterford) as tanning agents had to be imported from around the globe. Secondly, tanneries are better suited to a rural location as the smell and waste are so obnoxious. And finally, there needs to be a lot of water available, coming in and going out of the factory. Water is brought in for the tanning itself and, however unsatisfactory it might be to modern sensibilities, a body of water was needed to dump the untreated waste. Dickens Leather in Dungarvan, located where the Colligan River meets the sea, could take water from the river and dump it into the sea afterwards. The tannery in Gorey had to have a huge waste pipe built, running several miles to the sea, suggesting that politics played a greater role than geography in choosing the town. The Portlaw tannery sat on a bend on the River Clodiagh, a tributary of the River Suir, again providing water on both sides. The site had previously been used for a cotton mill in the nineteenth century, run by a Quaker family. Indeed the town was purpose-built for its workers and, when the tannery finally opened, a former employee of the mill, aged 94, showed up and demanded to be given a job in his old haunt.
It turns out that Lemass was, in the end, somewhat regretful at having chosen Portlaw as the site of the first Irish tannery. The town, or perhaps village, was so small that the meal for the opening ceremony in 1935 had to be cooked in Waterford and transported to Portlaw. Fianna Fail might have gained more political traction by putting it into a town with a much larger population – such as Dungarvan – where the staff’s wages could be recirculated more easily, bringing bonhomie to a wider array of voters. Lemass’s choice of Portlaw was informed by government officials who underestimated the coming demand for leather as the state sought self-sufficiency. It quickly became clear that their estimate of 225,000 hides per annum was too low and so was a second estimate of 300,000 hides, made by Vincent Crowley, a Dublin-based solicitor who became Chairman of Irish Tanners and also the accountant for Dickens Leather.
Personnel
While the workers in Irish Tanners, Portlaw were local, the management group most certainly weren’t. Kennedy O’Brien became a director and general manager, running the day-to-day operations while his Dublin business ticked over. Crowley was chairman and the secretary was his employee, Dr Jeremiah Dempsey, another city-based professional with his finger in the provincial pie. Despite the name of the tannery, it was actually British-owned and Mary Daly notes this it was registered to the tariff-jumping “British entrepreneur who already owned Western Tanning of Bristol and Redvales Ltd. of Bury.” Presumably, this was HG Barlow, the Managing Director of Irish Tanners, Portlaw’s equivalent of Reginald Dickens who himself was also present at the opening ceremony, along with Dr Austie Casey and many other prominent men of County Waterford.
In retrospect, it makes sense to view Portlaw and Dungarvan as complementary businesses, run by an overlapping group of people, especially in the beginning. They were not in direct competition because Portlaw focussed on hard leather soles for shoes, taken from tougher cowhides, whereas Dungarvan would focus on soft leathers taken from sheepskins. We might also think of the Portlaw and Dungarvan tanneries as a three-way compromise between three societal forces. The provincial townspeople did the actual work, capital and industry expertise came from British entrepreneurs (but not the British state), while those based in Dublin functioned as intermediaries between the two.
However, a new law (The Control of Manufacturers Acts 1932-4) introduced by Fianna Fail required that the new industries not have majority control from a foreign company. Irish Tanners was in part funded by the Irish Credit Company, represented at the opening ceremony by its chairman, J.P. Colbert.4 The ICC was formed in 1933 in an effort to fund the new industries popping up around the country, and it is not much of a jump to imagine that the Dungarvan Tannery, with its complementary output, may have been envisioned as being a second branch of Irish Tanners. However, the ICC did not fund Dungarvan – perhaps it ran out of cash – so Irish capital had to be found from somewhere. We shall see in the next chapter that Reginald Dickens owned exactly half of the shares in Dickens Leather, and no capital came from the state. Thus the Irish interest had to be filled by someone, and Austie Casey and Joe Moloney stepped up to the
Managing Portlaw remained O’Brien’s primary focus, and by 1957 it was said to be the sixth largest tannery in the world, and managed by his son Bartholemew. His sons became ever more involved in the family business, and Kennedy’s urge to create employment and wealth for his family, saw him set up something of a corridor of his own tanneries stretching between Dublin and Waterford. The first of these was in Gorey (1936) and later in Milford, Co Carlow, Rathangan, Co Kildare and Carnew, Co Wicklow. Meanwhile, his operations in Dublin continued to grow. He had a team of ladies on one floor cutting upper leathers for the shoe repairmen of Dublin and another team producing metal parts for working boots, parts which previously had to be imported from England.
One final story should illustrate the continued importance of Kennedy O’Brien to the Irish leather industry, and its ultimate demise in the latter part of the twentieth century. Among his many ventures, O’Brien, along with his namesake son, began producing football boots and running shoes, under the brand name Kayobee, taken from their initials. Kayobee shoes were worn in 1956 by Ronny Delany when he won an Olympic Gold medal in the 1500m, Ireland’s first gold medal since 1932, and the first to be televised. The 1950s would turn out to be the high point of the Irish leather industry, before plastics began to be used, and protectionist policies were relaxed, by Lemass himself. Meanwhile, Kayobee shoes, like all regional brands, would be ousted by some of the most iconic brands in the world, and the Irish tanneries slowly faded into oblivion. Our Kennedy O’Brien died in 1959 and his business was liquidated in 1972. The Portlaw tannery, having let go of its staff over several phases, finally closed in 1985 and the derelict factory was finally sold in 2024.

Opening:

Ireland in 1937 was a land filled with the hope of coming prosperity.

While it was most certainly a repressive theocracy, it was also a state that had begun building towards self-sufficiency through the sudden emergence of an industrial sector thanks in part to the large tariffs that had recently been placed on imported goods.



The opening of Dickens Leather Factory, on Monday, 3 September, 1937 was a special day in the town’s history and it gives us the ideal opportunity to get introduced to the characters in the story and to understand who was who when the factory opened. Officially opened, that is, because the factory was already up and running for fully twelve months (GET DATES) and, given the circumstances, that was the hard part done, as we shall see.
The ceremony began with the arrival of Minister Sean Lemass, who was yet again made Minister of Industry and Commerce in the new Dáil of July 1937, where Fianna Fail rubberstamped their authority on the The Irish Free State, winning exactly 50% of seats, before reconstituting the state by the end of the year. Lemass had been most successful in his first ministerial term, opening up countless new factories around the state, including County Waterford’s other leather factory in the village of Portlaw.
Lemass alighted in Abbeyside, the village across the bridge from Dungarvan Town, and he we was met by a local priest and most of the directors of Dickens Leather. Fr T.B. Walsh was the Chairman of the Dungarvan Industrial Development Association, a group that included two local, Dr Michael Augustine Casey and Patrick J. Molony, the managing director of A. Molony and Sons (shipping?)This team had agitated hard to get the factory into Dungarvan and the factory in Portlaw proved to be a complementary stepping stone, in terms of both personnel and output. Portlaw’s produce was mostly based on hard cowhide leather, used in the soles of the shoes, whereas Dungarvan’s produce was mostly based on softer sheepskin leather, used for upper parts of the shoe and inner linings. Their leadership groups were also hugely overlapping. The Chairman of Dickens Leather was Mr Kennedy O’Brien who was becoming something leather baron across Ireland. He was CHAIR? of Portlaw, and his core business was as leather merchant in Dublin City. And the Managing Director was the eponymous Reginald Dickens from England, and his family’s core business was in Northampton, the most famous city in the world for leather and shoe production. Dungarvan and Portlaw, for him, were side ventures from his main business, run by Reginald and his brothers, and by their father before them since 1897.
The town was ready for its big day and once the men of influence had assembled, the triumphal procession could begin to slither through the freshly decorated streets, to the roars of the crowd, as cheer after cheer rent the air. Varicoloured bunting festooned the main streets and large banners welcomed the Minister to the town. The local Gardaí formed a bodyguard for Lemass and the parade was fronted by the Waterford Brass and Reed band playing familiar airs, many with a nationalistic bent, for the day was an expression of both national and local pride. The crowd filed in behind them like mass-goers forming a queue for communion and, on arrival at Quay Street, they were met by the hundred-plus men who worked in the factory nearby, at The Lookout, looking out at the wide expanse of Dungarvan Bay.
A temporary stand was erected and Lemass was greeted by Kennedy O’Brien in his capacity of Chairman of Dickens Leather. Meanwhile, the band played the National Anthem while the deep crowds looked on. Several welcoming addresses were made. First up were The Urban District Council and then Father Walsh himself. Not one, but two local Fianna Fail groups gave an address: the Padraig Pearse Cumann and the Cathal Brugha Cumannn and, finally, an unidentified of the factory’s workforce said some words, with no name given by any of the newspaper reports.
The last public address was made by Lemass himself. He thanked and congratulated the above-mentioned men of power, the workers and his Fianna Fail colleagues in the Cumainn, but also spoke the crowd themselves, noting the importance of the factory in generating employment and prosperity to the locality.
Afterwards, O’Brien presented Lemass with a symbolic gold key to the factory, and, with the church and local government and the politicians having all had their say, and with the band playing Faith of Fathers, it was time for the factory to be blessed solemnly by His Lordship, The Most Reverand Doctor Jeremiah Kinane, Bishop of Waterford and Lismore, ably assisted by the Parish Priest, The Very Reverand T. Canon O’Brien, and his curate, the above-mentioned Reverand TB Walsh.
Afterwards, Dickens gave the Bishop and Minister a guided tour of inspection of the factory

The factory was left open for the local hoards to investigate and one wonders how well supervised the machines were with children running round.
Later in the day, Lemass would point out how great it was that the factory was a truly local venture – and it certainly was for the staff employed in the factory. But the reality is that the directors were a mix of locals (Austie Casey and Joe Molony) with bigger fish.
In July 1937, Fianna Fail had yet again won the general election, and were continuing their policy of applying huge tariffs on imported goods, a policy which facilitated the growth of an unprecendented number of mid-sized factories around the state. Sean Lemass was again the Minister of Industry and Commerce, a position he would hold between 1932 and 1959 for for sixteen intermittent years.

title: What the Dickens!
text:
John Dickens opened his purpose-built factory in Northampton in 1900. By 1921 it was incorporated as Dickens Brothers Leather, although Reginald was the only brother involved in the Dungarvan tannery.
While Kennedy O’Brien might have been one of the few leathermen in all of Ireland, Reginald Dickens (also born in 1888) was one of several in his own family.1 They ran Dickens Brothers Ltd in Northampton, a city which was firmly at the centre of the leather and footwear industry in Britain and indeed the world. However, with three older brothers ahead of him, two of them a full decade older, Reginald’s best chance of individual success perhaps lay in pastures abroad.
Grandfather Dickens was a shoe maker in the village of Walgrave, about ten miles outside Northampton, and his son John Dickens, born in 1860, became a leather merchant and a master currier during the 1880s and 90s. Hebegan leather production in the family workshop, but also employed a number of other workers operating from their own backyard workshops. Such small-scale operations had also been common in Ireland in the nineteenth century, but instead of consolidating into larger enterprises in harmony with technological improvements, as they did in Britain, the Irish industry dwindled out of existence thanks in part to the ravaging effects of the famine and the ever-increasing export of livestock ‘on the hoof’ from Ireland to Britain.
The Dickens family were of the Baptist persuasion and such non-conformists were disqualified from going to the main English universities. These groups focused on industry and in Ireland this is most familiar among Quaker families such as the Jacobs, the Bewleys and the Odlums. John Dickens doubled up as a lay preacher and was deeply involved in the local Baptist church. He was strict and particularly against the pernicious effects of alcohol. However, he was not shy of work and, being entrepreneurial, he was bound for the nearby city with its shiny opportunities. By 1897, now aged 37, he had established a successful leather business on Victoria St, in the city’s boot and shoe district, where many non-conformists congregated. In 1899 he bought a row of six cottages, had them demolished, and had a purpose-built factory in their place, helped a total of £4000 in loans, split between the bank and his father-in-law, a Mr Pebody. The factory was operational the following year but, sadly, John died in 1903. Like Michael J Casey, he had five sons and one daughter. The eldest two, Arnold and Alfred, took over the business, prospered, and by 1908 they had secured trade deals in the United States, Canada and other Commonwealth states, although it is not known if they had dealings within Ireland.
When his father died, Reginald was still only a lad of 14, attending Northampton Grammar School. It is not clear exactly when he joined the family business, but it is most likely that he spent much of the next decade working there before the war broke out. He spent the war years in active service, and according to his service numbers, he would have been a reservist in England before the war even began, so he would have been one of the first on the battlefield. He was a field driver for the Royal Field Artillery, a job that involved driving up to six horses as a time as they lugged artillery across the battlefield. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCsyd-FfGhk
Meanwhile, the factory was contracted by the government to produce leather for the army. Reginald survived the war and rejoined the family business in 1919, gaining plenty more experience, before eyeing up the emerging opportunities in the neighbouring Irish Free State. It is well worth noting that while Dickens Leather in Dungarvan had over 100 men working, there were only about 50 men on the floor in Northampton, before mechaninisation in the 1950s reduced the need for so many manual workers. This figure also gives us some context for how large the Dungarvan operation actually was. Furthermore, in the scramble for business contracts in the puritanical – or family-oriented – Irish Free State, Dickens Bros’ habit of employing only men was seen by the Irish ministry as a positive.
Dickens Leather Bros, at it became known in the 1920s, would stay operational, and in the family, until 2019, under the watch of Reginald’s nephew Brian (1938-2025). After it closed, he claimed the business was the longest running finished leather manufacturing business in Northampton, and perhaps the oldest in the UK.

title: The Fr Casey Collection
text: The Fr Casey collection includes hundreds of images he amassed during his lifetime, including many lantern slides (above) which he would have projected to his large audiences in America and later in Ireland. The collection is now housed by the National Photography Archive in Temple Bar, Dublin, where it has been partly sorted and labeled.

title: The Fr Casey Collection
text:
Beautiful Ireland



The images chosen by Casey give us an idea of the image of Ireland he wanted to convey to his diasporan audience in America. We have a map on the unpartitioned island, some shrivelled up shamrocks, and meticulously preserved castles dating from an ancient time that remains barely fathomable to a New World audience.


The slides that Casey chose portray a land of “emerald hills, the castles of ancient prestige, as well as the modern cities, towns, people and social customs of the old land’, according to one contemporary newspaper report. We have a map of the unpartitioned island, some shrivelled up shamrocks, and meticulously preserved castles dating from an ancient time that must have seemed barely fathomable to his New World audience. There’s The Rock of Cashel, a round tower on Devinish Island in Fermanagh, and the rope bridge near the Giant’s Causeway. Casey includes some images of County Watarford, including the Historic Town of Lismore, Reginald’s Tower in Waterford City, and his own parish church in Dungarvan. There’s an image of a thatched cottage and one (I didn’t see) of Croagh Patrick, a pilgrimage site. There’s a notable lack of barren wild landscapes of the kind Americans like to visit nowadays (e.g. the Ring of Kerry, The Burren, Donegal, etc). There is one of Kilkee in West Clare but I see it either so I don’t know if it’s a photo of the town or the nearby landscapes.

title: The Fr Casey Collection
text:
Friends of Irish Freedom



Casey includes an image of the already ancient Theobald Wolfe Tone, but no slides show the Fenian Rebellion of 1867


It is interesting to note Casey’s choice of rebels and reformers. One slide shows Wolfe Tone, who led the failed rebellion of 1798. Another shows the Wicklow Parliamentarian, Charles Stewart Parnell, his deceased body lying in state. Finally, there is bronze statue of Fr William Casey in Abbeyfeale, Co. Limerick, the “peoples’ priest”. This Casey – who is also no relation to our subject – must have functioned as quite the role model for our Richard. He was a Gaelgeoir, a musician, a GAA man, and temperance activist, which I suspect Fr Richard was too. Fr William was most active in the Land League, for which he gained huge local support, and so too was Fr Richard’s uncle – another Fr Richard J Casey – to whom I shall one day return. There are no slides related to the Fenian Uprising of 1867, even though its veteran John Devoy had become the leading Republican in New York by the time of Casey’s lectures. This may be because the Fenians tried to keep a low profile and used codenames for their gatherings. Plus the audience may simply have been familiar with Devoy or the recently-deceased O’Donovan Rossa, and would thus have had no need to slides of them.
In my next post, we will see that Casey’s talks may have been part of a series of covert funding campaigns for the Revolution.. For example. one 1919 soirée saw both a céilidhe and Casey’s (music-filled) presentation. It was held by the Gaelic Society in New York. We shall also see newspaper reports of how Casey’s was not afraid to include his thoughts on the English oppressors of the Irish people.

Lourdes





In 1913, Casey also seems to have been part of very large group of Irish pilgrims to Lourdes: 3000 in total, including 300 priests and another 200 with a religious affiliation, according to the newspaper clippings above, one in French and one in English, and both of which Casey had upscaled into a lantern slide. This pèlerinage seems to have been one of the events of the year for the Lourdais and it would have been quite the journey for the pilgrims on the boat and train. It would no doubt have been quite the badge of honour in New York too. Even today my parents are very proud of their visit to the miraculous site – although they did cycle there (and back) from Paris during their 1990s cycling-getaway heyday.





There are plenty of photos taken in Lourdes do but I never got to see them. I had it in my head Casey went later but perhaps he went several times, as has since become common. I used to live beside two spinster sisters, just off Meath St, and they had then been volunteering on trips to Lourdes for 25 uninterrupted years, and their living room contained a shrine full of tat. I must drop in some time, armed with a bottle of their beloved vodka, and excavate a few stories from them.

Back in The Free State



This slide shows General Richard Mulcahy hoisting the flag of Irish Free State in 1922


Casey returned to Ireland in the summer of 1920 and moved to Bray soon after, before finally joining hte Defence Forces as chaplain in 1924. Before seeing the collection, I hadn’t realised that he continued to give projected talks after his return to Ireland but the age of the slides indicate that he must have. There are several slides dating from Casey’s time back in the Auld Sod, and the ones I saw relate to the newly formed Free State in the early 1920s. One shows General Richard Mulcahy hoisting the Irish flag in 1922 and one shows an aerial view of a damaged Four Courts, bombed and burnt during the Civil War. Another shows troops marching to Dolphin’s Barn Barracks from DMP Barracks (which is now the public library in an oddly vacant part of Inchicore). Another aerial shot shows President Cosgrave returning to Monkstown from a League of Nations meeting in 1923, being greeted by crowds who were clearly delighted to see the new state being recognised among the nations of the world. Casey’s scrapbook contains a flyer from April 1922 where he spoke to the Catholic Young Men’s Society on Buckingham St (on the town side of Phibsborough), but the above slides were mostly taken after that.



Casey spoke to the CYM society in Dublin in 1922, but must have continued beyond this, judging by the date of the slides.




The Archivists’ Records



Catalogue details of the Fr Casey collection


Above is the full catalogue record of the collection, with information about what is in the collection, the number of photos, slides and negatives, their condition, and the subject matter. If I can get back in with John Harte, there will be plenty more to sift through.


Yet more Caseys
Finally, I should note that, while I was the first member of the public to view the collection, I wasn’t the first to request to view it. It turns out that a genealogist called Paul O’Donnell was in touch with Nora and her colleague Barbara but Covid interrupted his efforts to view it and then, shurlook, you know yourself. So while I was in on site, Barbara found his email, contacted him with my details, and by the end of the day we had a 40 minute phone conversation about the Casey family. It turns out that O’Donnell is married to a Casey from Grawn – the crowd who moved in there after it was sold – and he has done quite a bit of work on the wider family, although his brain is fried by the incessant recurrence of people with the same name (Richard, Pierce, Michael, etc). I will write about that conversation soon, or perhaps after I trek Co Galway to find out more from him.
